newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's KDD in tie-up with long-distance carrier.
newsitem.headline: Japan's KDD in tie-up with long-distance carrier.

text.p: In the latest round of realignment in the telecommunications sector, Japan's biggest international operator, KDD, announced on Monday a broad business partnership with domestic long-distance carrier DDI Corp.
Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co and DDI said they would start offering seamless phone services in October combining their long-distance and international services under a unified brand.
The rates for the new service, to be offered to individual users through a Japanese unit of KDD, will be about 20 percent lower than those of their competitors, a KDD spokeswoman said.
KDD and DDI will offer the service to individual users by connecting to Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp's (NTT) local call networks.
KDD and DDI are also discussing joint investment plans and the development of new Internet and multimedia services, but details have not yet been worked out, she said.
However, KDD denies speculation it plans to merge with DDI.

"Our strategy is to join hands with different partners in different business areas," a KDD spokeswoman said, adding that KDD is in talks on business tie-ups with other Japanese long-distance operators, including Toyota Motor Corp affiliate Teleway Japan Corp.
"We are not considering a merger with DDI for the time being," she said.
KDD will start offering domestic leased line service for corporate users later in July, its first move into the huge domestic phone market since the firm was established in 1953.

Last year it said it was considering forming business partnerships with telecom affiliates of electric power utilities, which offer long-distance services to a small group of corporate users via fibre-optic networks.
Japan's telecom industry shake-up was sparked earlier this year by deregulation measures that freed telecom titan Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT) to move into international services.

Taking its cue from the liberalisation drive, another long-distance operator, Japan Telecom Co, wasted no time announcing a plan to merge with ITJ Corp, a small international operator, stirring speculation that their competitors would immediately follow suit in order to survive.
A Japan Telecom spokesman said the company's scheduled merger with ITJ on October 1 would allow it to offer services at rates lower than those of the KDD-DDI group.
"We'll certainly offer more than a 20 percent discount (to current rates)," a Japan Telecom spokesman said.
NTT, for its part, will launch an international service in September.
